articles.headline: Uvalde Had Prepared for School Shootings. It Did Not Stop the Rampage.
articles.snippet: Uvalde officials had trained to confront gunmen and, like other schools around the country, had invested in security.
articles.abstract: Uvalde officials had trained to confront gunmen and, like other schools around the country, had invested in security.
articles.lead_paragraph: In August 2020, law enforcement officers from five agencies converged inside the hallways of a school in Uvalde, Texas, their guns drawn, role-playing how they would halt a gunman.
articles.byline: By Mike Baker and Dana Goldstein

articles.headline: A Face Search Engine Anyone Can Use Is Alarmingly Accurate
articles.snippet: PimEyes is a paid service that finds photos of a person from across the internet, including some the person may not want exposed. “We’re just a tool provider,” its owner said.
articles.abstract: PimEyes is a paid service that finds photos of a person from across the internet, including some the person may not want exposed. “We’re just a tool provider,” its owner said.
articles.lead_paragraph: For $29.99 a month, a website called PimEyes offers a potentially dangerous superpower from the world of science fiction: the ability to search for a face, finding obscure photos that would otherwise have been as safe as the proverbial needle in the vast digital haystack of the internet.

articles.headline: As Russia Diverges From the Global Economy, Soviet-Style Scarcity Looms
articles.snippet: With soaring prices and shortages of basic goods, the Russian people and businesses large and small are feeling the pinch.
articles.abstract: With soaring prices and shortages of basic goods, the Russian people and businesses large and small are feeling the pinch.
articles.lead_paragraph: Gripped by heavy economic sanctions and increasingly isolated from Western suppliers, Russia worked on Thursday to keep its factories and businesses running and stave off a return to Soviet-era scarcity.
articles.byline: By Patricia Cohen, Eshe Nelson, Valeriya Safronova and Michael Levenson

articles.headline: How Does It End? Fissures Emerge Over What Constitutes Victory in Ukraine
articles.snippet: Differing objectives foreshadow a coming debate about what position President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine and his Western allies would take if negotiations to end the conflict finally get going.
articles.abstract: Differing objectives foreshadow a coming debate about what position President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine and his Western allies would take if negotiations to end the conflict finally get going.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Three months into Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, America and its allies are quietly debating the inevitable question: How does this end?
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger, Steven Erlanger and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Senators Grasp for a Bipartisan Gun Deal, Facing Long Odds
articles.snippet: A group of Republicans and Democrats have begun an urgent set of talks aimed at reaching an elusive compromise on new gun laws. After a decade of failure, can this time be different?
articles.abstract: A group of Republicans and Democrats have begun an urgent set of talks aimed at reaching an elusive compromise on new gun laws. After a decade of failure, can this time be different?
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After the deadliest school shooting in a decade, a small group of Republican and Democratic senators have begun an urgent and uphill effort to strike a compromise on new gun laws, voicing hope that a wave of collective outrage at the slaughter of 19 children and two teachers could finally conquer a decade of congressional paralysis.
articles.byline: By Emily Cochrane and Catie Edmondson

articles.headline: Accused of Cheating by an Algorithm, and a Professor She Had Never Met
articles.snippet: An unsettling glimpse at the digitization of education.
articles.abstract: An unsettling glimpse at the digitization of education.
articles.lead_paragraph: A Florida teenager taking a biology class at a community college got an upsetting note this year. A start-up called Honorlock had flagged her as acting suspiciously during an exam in February. She was, she said in an email to The New York Times, a Black woman who had been “wrongfully accused of academic dishonesty by an algorithm.”

articles.headline: Children called for help from inside classrooms in Uvalde. The police waited.
articles.snippet: A new timeline from the state police raised questions about whether lives could have been saved with swift action.
articles.abstract: A new timeline from the state police raised questions about whether lives could have been saved with swift action.
articles.lead_paragraph: UVALDE, Texas — Furtively, speaking in a whisper, a fourth-grade girl dialed the police. Around her, in Room 112 at Robb Elementary School, were the motionless bodies of her classmates and scores of spent bullet casings fired by a gunman who had already been inside the school for half an hour.
articles.byline: By J. David Goodman, Edgar Sandoval, Karen Zraick and Rick Rojas

articles.headline: ‘Escalation of Secrecy’: Global Brands Seek Clarity on Xinjiang
articles.snippet: Companies that sourced cotton from the region in China are weighing evidence of forced labor, a lack of visibility into operations and new regulation.
articles.abstract: Companies that sourced cotton from the region in China are weighing evidence of forced labor, a lack of visibility into operations and new regulation.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the summer of 2019, an executive at Patagonia got a phone call from a trusted auditor working in China. A planned trip to visit some cotton farms in the region of Xinjiang wasn’t going to happen. Soon other barriers were thrown up. Information from suppliers in the region ran dry.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Sapna Maheshwari

articles.headline: Americans Keep Spending Even as Inflation Erodes Buying Power
articles.snippet: To keep up with rising prices, Americans are saving less, but economists expect expenditures to slow in the months ahead.
articles.abstract: To keep up with rising prices, Americans are saving less, but economists expect expenditures to slow in the months ahead.
articles.lead_paragraph: Americans built up trillions of dollars in savings during the pandemic. Now, with prices rising at their fastest pace in decades, they are tapping that stockpile to keep on spending.
articles.byline: By Ben Casselman and Lydia DePillis

articles.headline: Gas Prices Hit New Highs as Summer Driving Season Starts
articles.snippet: A gallon has jumped by about 50 cents over the last month as Russia’s war in Ukraine has continued to unsettle the global energy market.
articles.abstract: A gallon has jumped by about 50 cents over the last month as Russia’s war in Ukraine has continued to unsettle the global energy market.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — With the Russian invasion of Ukraine grinding on, drivers will have to shell out a lot more to fill up their cars as the summer travel season begins this Memorial Day weekend.
